Architecture Design Review.Advice: A "Designed-for-Operability" approach implies that operability features need to be designed into the Architecture of the application.  The right architectural decisions can make requirmenents like availability and redundancy easy or hard to implement.

Observability.Advice: Monitoring aka "observability" is the key foundation to great ops - the more information you have about your applications the faster you can find what's wrong, or about to go wrong, and prevent it or fix it.

Documentation.Advice: Despite what some people might think, the need for good documentation hasn't gone away. High level architecture diagrams, well-written repo READMEs, runbooks and playbooks (along with other forms of documentation) can help reduce toil, reduce MTTR and improve availability.

Testing.Advice: Automated testing enables tests to be run quickly and frequently. It enables new features to be added with a high degree of confidence that existing functionality will not be broken. As such it is a key enabler for delivering software frequently in smaller increments.

Performance.Advice: Understanding the performance characteristics of your application is critical to being able to size your infrastructure appropriately to customer demand. Load testing your application prior to launch with as realistic workloads as possible is a great first step, but you also need to be monitoring performance in real-time. Modern Application Performance Management (APM) tools are a key part of your monitoring arsenal.

Deployment Strategy.Advice: There are a number of technical practices that are core to DevOps: Continuous Integration, Continuous Deployment/Delivery, Test Driven Development, Refactoring, and Code Review. The resources here are good overviews. For more in depth results see the detailed report for DevOps Practices.
